subject: RE: [junit] Non-indexed collections (RE: assertEquals(array1, arr ay2))
msgSnippet: True, true... :) ... http://explorer.msn.com/intl.asp To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to: junit-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com Your use of Yahoo!
messageBody:
True, true... :)

> -----Original Message-----
> From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains762@...]
> Sent: Monday, July 30, 2001 8:38 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Non-indexed collections (RE: assertEquals(array1,
> array2))
>
>
> >This only works for arrays that must be ordered. What
> about unordered
> >arrays? [...]
>
> Jason, I think you mean "not indexed". Arrays are not
> "ordered" (in the
> mathematical sense), they are "indexed". If you need a
> collection that is
> not indexed, use either java.util.Set if the elements are
> unique, or a class
> called Bag if the elements are not unique. A bag contains
> possibly many
> copies of an element, but with no index.
>
> Either way, arrays are not the answer. :)
>
> Your algorithm, of course, is perfectly fine. I wouldn't
> say "don't use it,"
> but rather, "don't get to the point where you'd want to
> use it." At that
> point, create a class.
>
> JBR.
>
